item.description:
The Greater Boston Humanists have a most pleasant tradition, celebrated every June, to gather for brunch and listen to a lecture. If you'd like to attend -- even if you've not been to a GBH event before -- you can RSVP by writing to Tom Ferrick, thomasferrick@gmail.com, or giving him a call at 617-547-1497.

You'll be asked to pay your $22 for the meal at the restaurant, with check or cash. The meal begins at 1 PM.  Remember, you may park free in the MIT Lot on Windsor St. 

Directions: in Cambridge’s Central Square area, turn from Massachusetts Avenue onto Main Street.  After passing by the Royal East on your right, a pink building, take the next right, Windsor Street, and turn into the first parking lot on your LEFT, repeat, LEFT.

After food and some announcements, there will be a timely and thoughtful talk from Dr. Leonard Bernstein, entitled EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION IS THE IMPERATIVE.  He is a Board Member of Greater Boston Humanists, and a resident of Brookline. Most people would agree that statistics and news headlines suggest there is a crisis in education and the finger of fault moves wildly and accusingly.  Dr. Bernstein formulates his case in this manner:

“When people speak about an educational system for primary and secondary school they are generally referring to the K1 - 12 format. They also may think this process is the most important part of making an educated person, a good citizen and a person able to reason and function well in society. But is it? The answer is no. It appears that the most critical period for the childhood learning experience is from birth through age 5. Dr. Bernstein will talk about the factors involved in the importance of these years and will make the case for the importance of early childhood education and intervention. He will present some evidence as to what can and has to be done and how all this relates to societal demands for its workforce. He will endeavor to make the case that it is imperative to do so.

In order for humanistic concepts to take hold in a person's mind, a mind capable of being able to think critically and reasonably, a mind with the tools to do so is required. As Dr. Bernstein will try to show, for too many children, the chance to start the thinking process is thwarted by societal and parental strictures. Is early childhood education the way to go to achieve educational, let alone humanistic, goals? Dr. Bernstein will present material that he hopes will allow you to make your own conclusions.”
